title: After Foster Care, Dancing Her Way to Independence
text:
She entered treatment for depression and went on medical leave before the end of her first semester. After she returned at the beginning of the next school year, she said, she was the target of racist comments from her roommates . Her time at N.Y.U. took a turn for the worse after she was sexually assaulted; in the throes of depression, she said, she attempted suicide. She took a second medical leave, and dropped out for good in January 2015.

Ms. Manning found solace in the theater, joining the Possibility Project , a nonprofit that uses the performing arts to help teenagers build relationships. She also found a crucial source of support in her third, and final, foster mother, Janice Harper. She encouraged Ms. Manning, who was working full time at a Walgreens, to resume her education.

“She helped me out of that cycle of blaming myself or feeling like I wasn’t good enough,” Ms. Manning said.

In 2016, Ms. Manning enrolled at Hunter College with plans to major in theater. Then she briefly considered studying dance before ultimately deciding to major in social work. She said she wanted to use her experiences in foster care to help others navigate the system and transition out of it.

She expects to graduate next year . “I was the first person in my family to graduate high school and the first one to go to college,” she said, “so I’m excited to be the first one to graduate as well.”
description: Araya Manning spent four years in New York City’s foster system. Now 24, she is studying social work at Hunter College and has found an outlet in dance.
